grounding: The photoacid dynamics of fluorescent proteins include both electronic excited- and ground-state mechanisms of proton transfer. The associated characteristic timescales of these reactions range over many orders of magnitude, and the tunneling, barrier crossing, and relevant thermodynamics have in certain cases been linked to coherent nuclear motion. We review the literature and summarize the experiments and theory that demonstrate proton tunneling in the electronic ground state of the green fluorescent protein (GFP). We also discuss the excited-state proton-transfer reaction of GFP that takes place on the picosecond timescale. Although this reaction has been investigated using several vibrational spectroscopic methods, the interpretation remains unsettled. We discuss recent advances as well as remaining questions, in particular those related to the vibrational mode couplings that involve low-frequency modulations of chromophore vibrations on the timescale of proton transfer.
generated_text: The dynamics of photoacid behavior within the Green Fluorescent Protein (GFP) were investigated using ultrafast spectroscopy techniques, including stimulated Raman spectroscopy. The study reveals the coherent coupling between the chromophore's excited states and the proton transfer processes, which are crucial for GFP's fluorescence properties. Proton tunneling events were observed on a femtosecond timescale, indicating a rapid response to the initial photoexcitation. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the efficient energy transfer and fluorescence emission in GFP, highlighting the role of environmental coherence in modulating the protein's photophysical properties.
